Everyone seems to be more or less agreeing, so I'll offer a dissenting
opinion ;-)

I subscribe to the idea that comments are a code smell - in this case a
test smell - and I try to get rid of the smell rather than trying to
deodorize it with a comment - in this case a message.

I run my unit tests inside Intellij and if a test fails, Intellij
immediately shows me three things :

- the name of the test that failed

- the source code for the test (with the failing line highlighted)

- the stack trace for the failure


If the test is short enough, it's usually quite obvious what the failure
represents.

If the details of the assertion are not straightforward, I'll Extract
Method to create a higher level assertion. E.g.,

public void testEmptyTag() throws IOException {
out.startElement("tag");
out.endElement("tag");

assertResult("<tag/>");
}


If the test fails, I'll see :

testEmptyTag
============

Expected:<tagx/>
Actual :<tag/>

at XmlWriterTest.assertResult(XmlWriterTest.java:143)
at XmlWriterTest.testEmptyTag(XmlWriterTest.java:41)



I find that the stack trace gives me plenty of information to understand
the failure and that more text is not necessarily better.

Of course, if I can't find a way to make the test clearer, I'll add a
message to the assertion :-)

Kevin
